facts.text: Writ Petition No. 215 of 1972 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of fundamental rights

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 215 of 1972. Under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for the en- forcement of fundamental rights.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Dua J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Dua J.-The petitioner was arrested on November 8, 1971 pursuant

facts.text: Petitioner arrested on November 8, 1971 pursuant to detention order of same date under section 3(1)(a)(iii) read with section 3(2) of Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner was arrested on November 8, 1971 pursuant to the order of detention of the same date passed under sub-s.  1  a   iii  read with sub-s.  2  of S. 3 of the Maintenance of internal Security Act, 26 of 1971  hereinafter called, the Act .

facts.text: Grounds of detention served on petitioner and matter reported to State Government on November 8, 1971

anchor.surface_text: The grounds of detention were also served on him and the matter reported to the State Government on that very day.

facts.text: State Government accorded approval on November 16, 1971 and made report to Central Government

anchor.surface_text: On November 16, 1971 the State Government accorded its approval and made the necessary report to the Central Government.

facts.text: Case placed before Advisory Board on December 3, 1971

anchor.surface_text: The case was placed before the Advisory Board on December 3, 1971.

facts.text: Petitioner's representation received by State Government on December 6, 1971

anchor.surface_text: On December 6. 1971 the petitioners representation was received by the State Government

facts.text: Petitioner's representation considered by State Government on January 8, 1972, nearly 33 days after receipt

anchor.surface_text: but it was companysidered on January 8, 1972 nearly 33 days after its receipt.

facts.text: Advisory Board gave its decision on January 13, 1972

anchor.surface_text: The Advisory Board gave its decision on January 13, 1972

facts.text: Order of detention affirmed by State Government on January 22, 1972

anchor.surface_text: and the order of detention was affirmed by the State Government on January 22, 1972.

facts.text: Detenu communicated of the order on January 25, 1972

anchor.surface_text: The detenu was companymunicated of this order on January 25, 1972.

facts.text: Only ground raised by detenu is undue delay in State Government considering his representation

anchor.surface_text: The only ground raised on behalf of the detenu before us is that the State Government companysidered his representation after undue delay

facts.text: Delay of 33 days in considering representation explained in para 8 of counter-affidavit due to go-slow movement, increase in detention work, file movement delay

anchor.surface_text: the said representation of the detenupetitioner companyld number be companysidered by the State earlier, inter alia, on the following grounds  a  that the go-slow movement launched by the State Government employees sometime back caused some dislocation in office work companyse- quential increase in the pending work and delay in disposal.  b  that due to increase of the volume of work relating to detentions under the said Act there was companysiderable pressure of work and in companysequence whereof disposal of urgent matters were also delayed.  c  that due to aforesaid grounds, movement of files was delayed and the records were number readily available

facts.text: War with Pakistan from December 3, 1971 to December 17, 1971 when India declared ceasefire

anchor.surface_text: No doubt there was war with Pakistan from December 3, 1971 to December 17, 1971 when India unilaterally declared ceasefire

facts.text: Things could not be normal in State of West Bengal during war days and some time thereafter

anchor.surface_text: and in the State of West Bengal naturally things companyld number be quite numbermal during the war days and perhaps also during some time thereafter.

facts.text: Petitioner applied to Calcutta High Court for writ of habeas corpus, Crl. Misc. No. 958 of 1972, still pending

anchor.surface_text: In the companynter-affidavit it is averred that the petitioner appears also to have applied to the Calcutta High Court for a writ of habeas companypus  Crl. Misc. No. 958 of 1972  which is still Pennding there.

facts.text: Petitioner stated he had not appealed to Calcutta High Court

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner has in his application in this Court stated that he had number appealed to the Honble High Court at Calcutta.

facts.text: Detenu-petitioner is a notorious thief of copper wires and cables

anchor.surface_text: We are number unmindful of the fact that in the companynter- affidavit it is stated that the detenu-petitioner is a numberorious thief of companyper wires and cables

anchor.surface_text: and after stating the objectionable activities of the detenu and after referring to the incidents mentioned in the grounds of detention it is asserted that the detenu-petitioners activities seriously disrupted telegraphic companymunication system of the railways and caused dislocation of railway service.

facts.text: Writ petition allowed and detenu-petitioner directed to be set at liberty forthwith

anchor.surface_text: This writ petition is accordingly allowed and the detenu- petitioner directed to be set at liberty forthwith.

facts.text: State Government delay in considering representation was unintentional and beyond control

anchor.surface_text: I further state that the said delay was unintentional and was caused for such reasons beyond the companytrol of the State Government.

concepts.unlisted_label: Test for Unreasonable Delay in Considering Representation
concepts.unlisted_description: Multi-factor test based on facts and circumstances in preventive detention

issues.text: whether the State Government considered his representation after undue delay and that his detention must be considered to have become illegal on this ground

anchor.surface_text: The only ground raised on behalf of the detenu before us is that the State Government considered his representation after undue delay and that his detention must be considered to have become illegal on this ground.

issues.text: whether to decline to dispose of the present petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution or to postpone the hearing and await the decision of the Calcutta High Court

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances we do not think it would advance the cause of justice to decline to dispose of the present petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution or to postpone the hearing and await the decision of the Calcutta High Court.

issues.text: The question whether, or not the Indo Pak war or its after-effects on the normal functioning of the relevant Government departments reasonably contributed towards delay in the consideration of the detenu's representation

anchor.surface_text: The question whether, or not the Indo Pak war or its after-effects on the normal functioning of the relevant Government departments reasonably contributed towards delay in the consideration of the detenus representation must be left open to be decided when appropriately raised in a case.

arguments.claim: Representation must be considered expeditiously as practicable without avoidable delay, implicit in Art. 22(5)

anchor.surface_text: the Government must companyply with due promptitude with all the essential requirements of our Constitution as also of the Act relating to such detention. The representation made by the detenu to the State has, therefore, to, be companysidered as early as possible, or in other words as expeditiously as practicable without avoidable delay.

arguments.claim: Art. 22 prescribes minimum procedure for preventive detention laws; non-compliance with Art. 22 or mandatory law provisions vitiates detention even if valid initially

anchor.surface_text: Article 22, it may be recalled, prescribes the minimum procedure that must be included in any law permitting preventive detention and when the provisions of Art. 22 or of a law relating to a preventive detention providing for safeguards against arbitrary or illegal orders of detention are number companyplied.with then even if the detention may be valid ab initio it ceases to be valid as soon as violation of the provisions of Art. 22 or of the mandatory provisions of the law permitting preventive detention occurs

arguments.claim: No rigid time limit for considering representation; must be determined case-by-case; prima facie unreasonable delay requires satisfactory explanation by detaining authority

anchor.surface_text: No doubt numberrigid limit of time can be fixed within which the Government must companysider the representation and the question always requires determination on the facts and circumstances of each case. Any prima facie unreasonable delay must be satisfactorily explained by the detaining authority if the order of detention is required to be upheld by this Court.

arguments.claim: Explanation for 33-day delay is vague and unsatisfactory, no genuine obstacle shown

anchor.surface_text: The explanation for the delay in the present case is so extremely vague that we find it almost impossible to hold that due to the reasons companytained in the explanation embodied in the companynter-affidavit there was any real, genuine obstacle in the way of the Government in companysidering the representation within reasonable time and before the expiry of what seems to be an inordinate delay of 33 days.

arguments.court_reasoning: Does not absolve constitutional obligation to comply with safeguards in all situations

arguments.claim: Leisurely dealing with preventive detention safeguards inconsistent with constitutional emphasis on personal freedom

anchor.surface_text: We should like to repeat what seems to us to be well-settled that too leisurely a manner. of dealing with the statutory provisions relating to safeguards against arbitrary or illegal orders of preventive detention requiring urgent attention, as is the case before us, is wholly inconsistent with the fundamental importance attached by our Constitution to the question of personal freedom of the individual.

arguments.claim: 1971 Indo-Pak war and after-effects disrupted normal functioning in West Bengal, contributing to delay (judicial notice)

anchor.surface_text: No doubt there was war with Pakistan from December 3, 1971 to December 17, 1971 when India unilaterally declared ceasefire and in the State of West Bengal naturally things companyld number be quite numbermal during the war days and perhaps also during some time thereafter. These are the facts of which this Court can certainly take judicial numberice.

holdings.text: The explanation for the delay in the present case is so extremely vague that we find it almost impossible to hold that due to the reasons contained in the explanation embodied in the counter-affidavit there was any real, genuine obstacle in the way of the Government in considering the representation within reasonable time and before the expiry of what seems to be an inordinate delay of 33 days.

anchor.surface_text: The explanation for the delay in the present case is so extremely vague that we find it almost impossible to hold that due to the reasons contained in the explanation embodied in the counter-affidavit there was any real, genuine obstacle in the way of the Government in consid

holdings.reasoning_summary: Government's proffered reasons (go-slow, workload, file delays) deemed extremely vague and inadequate to justify 33-day delay as no genuine obstacle demonstrated.

holdings.text: No doubt no rigid limit of time can be fixed within which the Government must consider the representation and the question always requires determination on the facts and circumstances of each case. Any prima facie unreasonable delay must be satisfactorily explained by the detaining authority if the order of detention is required to be upheld by this Court.

anchor.surface_text: No doubt no rigid limit of time can be fixed within which the Government must consider the representation and the question always requires determination on the facts and circumstances of each case. Any prima facie unreasonable delay must be satisfactorily explained by the detaining authority if the order of detention is required to be upheld by this Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unreasonable delay test applied case-by-case; 33 days here prima facie unreasonable and unexplained.

holdings.text: Article 22 prescribes the minimum procedure that must be included in any law permitting preventive detention and when the provisions of Art. 22 or of a law relating to a preventive detention providing for safeguards against arbitrary or illegal orders of detention are not complied with then even if the detention may be valid ab initio it ceases to be valid as soon as violation of the provisions of Art. 22 or of the mandatory provisions of the law permitting preventive detention occurs.

anchor.surface_text: Article 22, it may be recalled, prescribes the minimum procedure that must be included in any law permitting preventive detention and when the provisions of Art. 22 or of a law relating to a preventive detention providing for safeguards against arbitrary or illegal orders of detention are not complied.with then even if the detention may be valid ab initio it ceases to be valid as soon as violation of the provisions of Art. 22 or of the mandatory provisions of the law permitting preventive detention occurs

holdings.reasoning_summary: Violation of Art. 22 safeguards, including expeditious consideration, renders ongoing detention invalid.

holdings.text: The representation made by the detenu to the State has, therefore, to be considered as early as possible, or in other words as expeditiously as practicable without avoidable delay. This has been repeatedly stated by this Court to be implicit in Art. 22(5) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: the Government must comply with due promptitude with all the essential requirements of our Constitution as also of the Act relating to such detention. The representation made by the detenu to the State has, therefore, to, be considered as early as possible, or in other words as expeditiously as practicable without avoidable delay. This has been repeatedly stated by this Court to be implicit in Art. 22(5) of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Expeditious consideration is judge-made doctrine implicit in constitutional safeguards, following prior precedents.

holdings.text: In these circumstances we do not think it would advance the cause of justice to decline to dispose of the present petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution or to postpone the hearing and await the decision of the Calcutta High Court.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances we do not think it would advance the cause of justice to decline to dispose of the present petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution or to postpone the hearing and await the decision of the Calcutta High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Insufficient evidence/details on alleged High Court proceeding; dismissing or postponing Art. 32 petition would not serve justice.

holdings.text: But this cannot absolve the authorities concerned of their constitutional obligation to give appropriate effect to the legal safeguards provided by the Constitution and the Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are not unmindful of the fact that in the counter- affidavit it is stated that the detenu-petitioner is a notorious thief of copper wires and cables... But this cannot absolve the authorities concerned of their constitutional obligation to give appropriate effect to the legal safeguards provided by the Constitution and the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Detenu's criminality or public risk does not excuse non-compliance with detention safeguards.

holdings.text: This writ petition is accordingly allowed and the detenu-petitioner directed to be set at liberty forthwith.

anchor.surface_text: This writ petition is accordingly allowed and the detenu- petitioner directed to be set at liberty forthwith.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Continued detention illegal due to procedural violation via unexplained delay.

anchor.surface_text: Article 22, it may be recalled, prescribes the minimum procedure that must be included in any law permitting preventive detention and when the provisions of Art. 22 or of a law relating to a preventive detention providing for safeguards against arbitrary or illegal orders of detention are not complied.with then even if the detention may be valid ab initio it ceases to be valid as soon as violation of the provisions of Art. 22 or of the mandatory provisions of the law permitting preventive detention occurs
This writ petition is accordingly allowed and the detenu- petitioner directed to be set at liberty forthwith.

edges.explanation: Holding h4 on expeditious consideration addresses the core of issue i1 on delay

anchor.surface_text: the Government must comply with due promptitude with all the essential requirements of our Constitution as also of the Act relating to such detention. The representation made by the detenu to the State has, therefore, to, be considered as early as possible, or in other words as expeditiously as practicable without avoidable delay. This has been repeatedly stated by this Court to be implicit in Art. 22(5) of the Constitution.
This writ petition is accordingly allowed and the detenu- petitioner directed to be set at liberty forthwith.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances we do not think it would advance the cause of justice to decline to dispose of the present petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution or to postpone the hearing and await the decision of the Calcutta High Court.
This writ petition is accordingly allowed and the detenu- petitioner directed to be set at liberty forthwith.

anchor.surface_text: The question whether, or not the Indo Pak war or its after-effects on the normal functioning of the relevant Government departments reasonably contributed towards delay in the consideration of the detenus representation must be left open to be decided when appropriately raised in a case.
